bibl.title: Letter from Ralph Cooper Hutchison to Philip Showalter Hench, February 5, 1940

div1.p: Hutchison congratulates Hench on receiving a honorary degree from their alma mater, Lafayette College.

div1.head: Letter from Ralph Cooper Hutchison to Philip Showalter Hench, February 5, 1940

opener.dateline:
THE PRESIDENT'S OFFICE
WASHINGTON AND JEFFERSON COLLEGE
WASHINGTON, PENNSYLVANIA
February 5, 1940

div1.p:
I am delighted to have your letter of January
thirty-first telling me fine news of the honorary
degree at Lafayette College upon which I congratulate
you with all of my heart and soul. No one ever received
that degree who deserved it more than you do. You need
have no hesitancy about accepting it. You deserve
it richly and absolutely and it is a becoming honor to
you.

It means a great deal to me for you to get it.
This letter which you have written means more to me and
I am deeply happy in regard to the whole matter.
However, I must disclaim responsibility, much as I would
wish to claim it. I may have had some indirect influence
in the matter, but I do not deserve the credit which you
give me for direct influence. I have on several occasions
talked with President Lewis about your fine accomplish-
ments and your work. A few weeks ago I had lunch in
Philadelphia with the chairman of the trustee committee
on honorary degrees at Lafayette College, and in the
course of our conversation I told him something of your
fine work. However, the subject of a degree for you
was not brought up at that time nor at any time, and I
didn't know anything about it. The picture is further
complicated by this fact which I now pass on to you.
On January twenty-fifth, six days before you wrote me the
letter about your degree at Lafayette, the trustees of
Washington and Jefferson College took action authorizing
the conferring of the degree of Doctor of Science upon
you at our Founders' Day Exercises in October. There-
fore, the degree at Lafayette College is actually a
disappointment to me and it would be far from my purpose
to induce them to give you a degree when I wanted to do
it myself.

On the other hand, the degree from Lafayette is
much better for you than our degree for two reasons. In
the first place, Lafayette is your college and it will
mean most to you to be recognized there, just as it did
to me when I received my honorary degree there. In the
second place, a degree from here might conceivably by
some people be thought of as the result of my friendship
for you. This is not true of course. You will recall, I
think I told you, that the degree was proposed not by
myself but by two members of the Board, one of them
Mr. Sherrard of Pittsburgh, and the other one a man from
elsewhere. So that the original motion for a degree for
Doctor Philip S. Hench
-2-
February 5, 1940
you was made several years ago by others, and I was
happy to remind them of that when the matter came up
this time. In any case, the degree is better from
Lafayette, though it is an intense disappointment to me
in one respect.

What this degree from Lafayette will do
to our degree in October I do not know. We will have
to put our heads together on that. We would seem to
be in the curious position of following the lead of
Lafayette, whereas Lafayette is actually thinking our
thoughts ahead of us. They are doing a few months ahead
of us what we have planned to do for several years, but
which we have been holding for this particular occasion.
It is an unfortunate mixup in one sense but there is
nothing to do about it and I am not sure what we should
do about your degree for Founders' Day. Later, you and I
will both have a judgment on it.

In any case, our hearty congratulations
on the Lafayette degree, our deep satisfaction that you
are being recognized as you should be, and our abundant
joy in the deep and beautiful friendship which finds
such perfect expression in your letter and which causes
me to rejoice in your honor as does nothing else possible.

So far as being at Commencement in Easton
I cannot do so. This year the Lafayette and the Washington
and Jefferson dates coincide. Our Commencement is on
Saturday, but our Baccalaureate is on Friday, the day
that you are at Lafayette. Of course, what you might do
is come on the sleeper that night after Commencement and be
at our Commencement too. There is no reason for this
but it would be nice to see you!

Well, I must close - congratulations,
good wishes. We are all deeply happy for you.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, Hutch Doctor Philip S. Hench
May Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
